subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Hi, Here is my feedback... not an expert one, but a junior one... maybe it helps to have one of those too :-D I like the general idea, but it make me think a
messageBody:
Hi,

Here is my feedback... not an expert one, but a junior one...
maybe it helps to have one of those too :-D

I like the general idea, but it make me think a few things...

what if the parameters are not that easy to construct...?
they are not plain type, but more complex classes...
i could mock them or just populate them in some way.
For example, one parameter could be a collection of things...
so i would need to create and populate the collection
(i don't think it's really a good example, you could always use Arrays.asList(),
but i hope it helps to understand my point )

In those cases, i couldn't just put them in the @Parameters array that easy.
Maybe i could use an initialize block, and have a static helper
method, to populate
the array.

Another thing i see, is that...
in one way, i like being able to see the test data with the test.
but, i may have the necessity to have it outside (i.e. if i have many
sets of test)
so, i would be nice to have an alternative way to set the parameters.

One last though. Having all the parameters in an array could make me
in some cases to forgot what that parameter is....they are not named after all..
I don't know this is a real problem, it's simpler the way it is...
but maybe if you have 5 o 6 parameters per testcase,
then you could easily forgot which is which... (is this expression
alright!??? :S)
But, i repeat, this may not be a problem of the parameter test...
maybe is the test that shouldn't need so many arguments...

Well, that's all...
hope it helps...

Regards,
Mariano Cortesi

On 9/16/05, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> All,
>
> Kent and I thought and coded last night about a mechanism for allowing
> parameterized test cases in JUnit 4. The results are in the Version4
> branch of CVS. We'd appreciate your feedback. For a glimpse of the
> mechanism in action, see org.junit.tests.ParameterizedTestTest.java:
>
> *http://tinyurl.com/7lyoh
>
> *Thanks,
>
> David Saff
